Description: Four joining fragments of floor and turn to rim of North Ionian black-figured pottery plate; cream slip; underside moulded with series of grooves; glaze bands over grooved areas; interior: black band at junction with rim, with added red band lined in white; in frieze, to left, probably a branch; central, two rather slim cocks confronted; the left-hand cock holds a branch in its beak (red dab beside its eye, red dabs on its neck, solid red chest, white on its body above its legs, red and white dots on its wing feathers, solid red at the start of the tail, alternating red and white tail feathers); the other end of the branch was apparently held by the other cock (most of its head is lost or damaged, but it had a red comb and possibly a red wattle, red chest, red and white on its wing and tail feathers; its legs are lost); between the two birds dangles a snake; on the right are three branches with red on some of the leaves.
Curator's comments: Probably belongs with GR 1888.6-1.551, analysed as Teian, and 1888.6-1.560.
Bibliographic references: Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GG.1122)
